description: Dive into "Capturing the Charm of Rhodes Town" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Capturing the Charm of Rhodes Town

places.generalDescription: Lindos Acropolis is an ancient citadel located on a steep cliff with stunning sea views. It offers a glimpse into prehistoric sites such as the nearby Acropolis of Lindos and Rhodes, along with ancient Minoan artifacts dating back over 3,000 years. Nature lovers can explore the Valley of Butterflies and enjoy miles of sunny beaches.

sources.snippet: I personally preferred discovering Rhodes Old Town, but I must admit that Lindos is the most ‚Äúinstagrammable‚Äù location in Rhodes, and the Acropolis is the best location for the most memorable photos. It could be because of the breathtaking views of the surroundings, or the ruins of the Greek buildings that overlook the sea. All I can say is that among all the acropolis that survived the test of time, this is probably a top contender for the title of Acropolis with the best views!
sources.shortName: The Best Rhodes Instagram Spots (+ a Map to Find Them)

sources.snippet: The next spot requires some cardio activity but what you get at the top is well worth the sweat. Sitting above the modern town of Lindos, the ancient Acropolis is one of the most spectacular viewing points in Rhodes. After venturing up the steep footpath, you can expect to be met with a clifftop enclosed by battlement ruins, as well as the remains of a temple and a 20 columned covered portico.
sources.shortName: 7 stunning selfie spots in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: After you took your pictures at the beach and jumped into the beautiful blue water it‚Äôs time to explore Lindos. While nearly all the other tourist are still exploring the acropolis you can easily discover the beautiful city center. It slightly gives some Santorini vibes with all those beautiful white houses and pink flowers.
sources.shortName: Most Instagrammable Places in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Speaking of, the Acropolis of Lindos is an absolute must-see while in Rhodes. It‚Äôs not only historically imposing but also aesthetically ‚Äì tall sandstone columns on top of a hill overlooking the eastern coast of Rhodes. The Temple of Athena sits at the very top of the hill and makes a fantastic background for photos.
sources.shortName: Rhodes, Greece: Full Guide to the Best Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: Perched atop a rocky hill, the Lindos Acropolis offers breathtaking views of the azure sea and white-washed buildings below. The journey to the top through narrow streets and ancient ruins is an adventure in itself, and the reward of capturing the panoramic scene is truly Instagram-worthy.
sources.shortName: The most instagrammable spots in Rhodes

sources.snippet: The Acropolis of Lindos dates back to the Hellenistic period. A part of it was restored by the Knights. The site today belongs to the Greek Ministry of Culture and much work is being done, by both Greek and foreign archaeologists, to protect this monument.
sources.shortName: Top 40+ Sights & Landmarks in Rhodes

sources.snippet: Then head to Lindos and stroll around the best archaeological site in Rhodes. The natural setting overlooking the sea from a precarious cliffside position just makes it even more dramatic.
sources.shortName: 51 Fun & Unusual Things to do in Rhodes, Greece

places.name: Lindos Acropolis

reviews.text:
Lindos Acropolis is a must-visit when on Rhodes. The combination of ancient ruins, dramatic cliffs and panoramic sea views is unforgettable. Tickets are 20 euros per adult and it's smart to buy them in advance to skip the line, we waited around 15 minutes. Along the way there are QR codes you can scan to buy tickets online, but if you're already close to the entrance, it might be quicker to just wait in line.
The path up is steep and not secured with handrails, so be careful, especially with kids. Wear good shoes and bring a hat or cap, as it gets very hot during the day. Once at the top, you're rewarded with stunning views over Lindos Bay and the white town below.
The site has some restored areas and informational signs. Go early if you want to avoid the crowds and the heat. A mix of history, nature and views that truly makes it one of the island's highlights. Worth every step.

The view and scenery were simply stunning!ü§©the only complain comes from the route to the temple, it is quite difficult as the terrain was hard to walk and no safety rails whatsoever exists, lots of other people going. Anyway, I'd recommend this as one-time visit if above points are not blockersüëçüèºtickets 20‚Ç¨/person at the gates

The Acropolis itself is impressive and fascinating to explore, but for me the real highlight was the breathtaking view of the surroundings - the beaches, Lindos, and the mountains. From the top, the scenery is absolutely spectacular.

We arrived right at 8:00 in the morning and were able to enjoy the site before it became crowded with other visitors. The walk up to the Acropolis is also very pleasant, offering beautiful side views of Lindos along the way.

Tickets cost ‚Ç¨20 per person, which may feel a little overpriced, but I would still highly recommend the experience - it's definitely worth it.

places.generalDescription: The Medieval City of Rhodes is a well-preserved walled town with grand palaces, Byzantine-era mosques, and charming piazzas lined with cafes. It's considered the best-preserved and most picturesque medieval city in Europe. The mystifying Street of the Knights leads to the magnificent Grand Master Palace, which has 160 rooms to explore. Other historical sites include the Archaeological Museum, Virgin of the Castle, Turkish baths, and mosques with tall minarets in small squares.

sources.snippet: Second to last, if you‚Äôre looking for another great spot for pictures amidst impressive ruins, try the fortifications of Rhodes. Here, you can walk through remnants or even walk up the steep stairs to get a view from higher up. Like other castles or ruins listed before, the rough sandstone with plants peeking through its cracks makes a unique backdrop and creates a dramatic image you don‚Äôt want to miss.
sources.shortName: Rhodes, Greece: Full Guide to the Best Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: Rhodes‚Äô medieval city is clearly the island‚Äôs must-see attraction. This UNESCO World Heritage site is the largest and best preserved fortified city in Europe!. When the knights of Saint-John arrived on the island in 1309, they decided to build this impressive citadel.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Rhodes | Attractions + Tips

sources.snippet: Discover one of the best-preserved medieval cities in Europe. Take advantage of Rodos Park‚Äòs exceptional location as your exploration starting point for this intriguing UNESCO World Heritage Site.
sources.shortName: Destination ‚Äì Rodos Park

places.name: Medieval City of Rhodes

reviews.text: Such a stunning place. The structures are beautiful and feel taken care of. Everywhere you go, there is something even grander than the next. The streets are bustling with restaurants and shops. It is definitely worth a visit if you're ever in Rhodes. We didn't go into any of the museums but I will make sure to do that if I ever visit Rhodes a third time.

Genuinely beautiful, I felt in awe no matter where I wandered üò≠ you'd turn a corner and suddenly you're faced with a 2000 year old temple or the literal castle. Shops are what you'd expect with mostly restaurants and tourist shops but honestly they were all still rather good quality. Honestly made my trip.

The medieval Old Town of Rhodes is a wonderful place to explore, with countless narrow streets and alleys that invite you to wander and discover. Walking through the stone pathways feels like stepping back in time, while still offering plenty of opportunities for shopping and browsing.
Most of the shops sell similar products, ranging from souvenirs and clothing to local crafts and jewelry. Prices can vary quite a bit from one store to another, so it is worth comparing before you buy. Another tip: many shopkeepers offer a better deal if you pay in cash rather than by card, so it's a good idea to keep some cash with you.
Overall, the Old Town combines history, charm, and a lively shopping experience, making it a must-visit during your stay in Rhodes.

places.generalDescription: The Castle of Monolithos, situated in the village of Monolithos on the island of Rhodes, Greece, is a 15th-century fortress perched atop a 240-meter rock. It offers picturesque views of the sea and surrounding landscape. The castle was strategically built by the Knights to control the sea and protect against pirate raids. Visitors can explore its ruins, including St. Panteleimon's Church and rescued cisterns.

sources.snippet: Situated at the westernmost point of Rhodes island, Monolithos Castle offers an exceptional location for observing the sky as the sun gracefully descends into the Aegean Sea. For an undisturbed and panoramic view of the horizon, the castle is the perfect spot to witness the sunset. Perched atop a rocky crag reaching a height of 236 meters (775 feet), the ascent to the castle requires a bit of climbing, so be sure to wear appropriate footwear, as some steps may be slippery.
sources.shortName: The 5 Best Sunset spots in Rhodes | Rhodes guide

sources.snippet: Adding to the best photo locations in Rhodes, you need to visit Monolithos Castle on the southwestern side of the island. After a 265 m hike up the hill, you‚Äôll find yourself with some of the best views in Rhodes: watch ocean waves break on cliffs or enjoy the sunset from this incredible viewpoint. What makes Monolithos so special and instagrammable is the castle‚Äôs arched ruins that give the impression that you‚Äôre looking out of a window.
sources.shortName: Rhodes, Greece: Full Guide to the Best Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: Near the southwest coast of the the island, the flat-roofed village of MonoÃÅlithos gives access to the nearby eponymous castle. Perched on a narrow pinnacle, with a 200-meter (656ft) sheer drop on all sides the ruined fortress dates from the 15th century. Spectacular sweeping views to the west make up for the fact that little remains of the original building, but a tiny chapel has been built within its walls.
sources.shortName: Best 15 Things To Do In Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: The castle of Monolithos is a 3km drive from the village of Monolithos while the distance from the city of Rhodes is about 69.5km. As soon as you reach the address, you need to continue your adventure on foot, following the steep footpath leading to the castle which lies about 265m high on a hill. It is a wonderful place for enjoying a beautiful sunset, but be prepared ‚Äì its not an insider tip.
sources.shortName: Most Instagrammable Places in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Resting above the village of Monolithos around seventy kilometres from Rhodes town, are the ruins of the 15 th century Monolithos Castle. Built by the Knights of Saint John to protect the area from pirates and enemies, nowadays the ruins pose as an ideal spot for selfie-taking. Say cheese, look out over the ocean and revel in the beauty that is the island of Rhodes, Greece.
sources.shortName: 7 stunning selfie spots in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Monolithos Castle is the highest vantage point for watching Rhodes sunsets. During the Middle Ages, the castle served as an important fortress because of its location on the steep cliff slope that stands at a height of 100 meters. Since it was never sieged at all, the structure continues to be relatively well-preserved through the years.
sources.shortName: 6 Best Places to Watch Sunset in Rhodes island

sources.snippet: Perched on top of a 236-meter rocky outcrop above the small village of Monolithos, this 15th-century Venetian Castle once protected the settlement from pirate raids. Today only the ruins remain, but the sweeping views alone are worth the steep hike. Can you spot the mountain of Akramytis?
sources.shortName: 51 Fun & Unusual Things to do in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: I‚Äôm talking about one of the most unforgettable locations on the west coast. This fortress was built under the dominance of the Knights of Saint John, to control the southwestern coast of Rhodes. The place is completely abandoned and left in ruins, but it maintained its charm.
sources.shortName: The Best Rhodes Instagram Spots (+ a Map to Find Them)

sources.snippet: Monolithos Castle: Perched on a rocky hill overlooking the sea, Monolithos Castle provides a stunning backdrop for watching the sunset. The combination of the medieval ruins and the golden hues of the setting sun creates a mesmerizing scene.
sources.siteName: Kariba Travel Group Excursions and Private Tours in Rhodes Island
sources.shortName: Stunning sunset views from various vantage points.-Kariba Travel

sources.snippet: The imposing Castle of Monolithos was constructed by the Venetians in Medieval times. It stands on top of a hill and offers a magnificent view of the sea. The castle is mostly ruined today but the view from the top is amazing.
sources.shortName: Top 40+ Sights & Landmarks in Rhodes
11 Very Best Things To Do In Rhodes, Greece

places.name: Castle of Monolithos

reviews.text: I really liked this place.  Its a small church type building on the top of rock/ cliff. It's a steady trek up the carved steps,  not easy,  but well worth the effort.  The views are spectacular.  Sheers drops can make you feel dizzy.... we went on a wet day and were at times in the clouds its that high up.  No charge to enter,  plenty of free parking.  The surrounding area is made of pine trees with the most beautiful smell.... definitely worth a visit.

Absolutely stunning views. Easily the best views over the mountains we've seen so far in Rhodes. Church is tiny but nice, but you go here for the view. Steepish climb up, but easily doable, you'd want decent shoes on. Nice little cafe at the bottom. But tight on parking but we found a spot easy enough. No charge to park or enter.
Drive over is pleasant winding through the mountains. Very glad we made the effort to come

Spectacular, take the extra drive to the beach.
If on a motorbike, becareful. 2 up may not be your best option.  Tight switchbacks
Loved the scenery of the drive.

places.generalDescription: Rhodes, a Dodecanese island in Greece, is renowned for its rich cultural and archaeological sites, as well as its sandy beaches and vibrant nightlife. Despite being a popular tourist destination, there are tranquil spots beyond the bustling areas. The island's history is deeply rooted, blending medieval and traditional Greek influences. Its natural beauty is evident in the picturesque beaches facing pine-covered mountainsides and charming seaside towns.

sources.snippet: If you want to enjoy a great day on a boat during your stay in Rhodes, here is my selection of the best boat trips. You just have to click on the orange links to access all the details and make your reservation. As these excursions are very popular, it‚Äôs very important that you book in advance!
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Rhodes | Attractions + Tips
Rhodes Instagram Spots in Greece
Destination ‚Äì Rodos Park

places.name: Rhodes

reviews.text: The Old Town and tip of the peninsula is where all the amazing sites and history are, incredible place.
Rhodes is such a beautiful city. Would definitely recommend visiting!
Beautiful island, near Turkey coast, very Green northern island. Stunning water. Amazing old Town, full of life.

places.generalDescription: Kallithea Springs, located by the seaside, is a historic spa with Art Deco architecture and a beautiful beach. Dating back to the 7th century B.C., it has been a popular destination for those seeking the therapeutic benefits of its thermal waters. The site also features the Rotunda, where visitors can relax and enjoy Greek cold coffee, as well as opportunities for snorkeling in the clear waters.

sources.snippet: A short drive away from Rhodes town on the island‚Äôs east coast, Kallithea Springs is a former spa. Built by the Italians in the early 20th century to harness the therapeutic powers of the area‚Äôs natural thermal springs, the complex features a splendid Art Deco folly, complete with domed pavilions and palm trees. One rotunda is home to a small exhibition space and a permanent gallery on the history of the spa.
sources.shortName: Best 15 Things To Do In Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: If you like frames and geometric elements, Kallithea Springs is your go to for your Instagram photos. This delightful art d√©co complex was built by the Italians around 1920, on the natural springs of Kallithea that have been known since ancient times. For a small fee, you can freely wander about the thermal buildings and take some jaw dropping photos.
sources.shortName: The Best Rhodes Instagram Spots (+ a Map to Find Them)

sources.snippet: Marvel at the majestic Moorish buildings of Kallithea Springs as you wander around this famous complex. The therapeutic healing properties of the water here once attracted patients from far and wide, and today you too can tap into the tranquillity of this restored spa.
sources.shortName: 51 Fun & Unusual Things to do in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: One of the most instagrammable spots in Rhodes is Kallithea Springs. This stunning whitewashed building features luxe Art Deco-styled floor tiles with artistic pebble mosaics and grand arches. It‚Äôs no wonder this is also an often-used wedding venue.
sources.shortName: Rhodes, Greece: Full Guide to the Best Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: Since ancient times, the water of Kallithea was known for its beneficial qualities. In 1927, the Italians inaugurated the spring facilities and built an impressive monument. After many years of decadence, the springs opened again in 2007.
sources.shortName: Top 40+ Sights & Landmarks in Rhodes

sources.snippet: You‚Äôre spending a few days in Rhodes, and you want to relax a bit?. Then, you should definitely go to Kallithea Springs!. The Springs are located East of the island, 9 km away from Rhodes City.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Rhodes | Attractions + Tips

places.name: Kallithea Springs

reviews.text:
Gorgeous place, we visited Kallithea Springs in June and really enjoyed our stay. The place is absolutely gorgeous, with stunning architecture that feels both historic and elegant. The small museum adds a nice cultural touch, and the on-site restaurant is lovely with great food and views.

The beach club was a highlight, so relaxing, with crystal-clear waters and the unique experience of swimming where natural spring water meets the sea. A perfect mix of history, beauty, and relaxation. Highly recommended!

Great spot for swimming and grabbing a drink, with a 3‚Ç¨ entrance fee, but sunbeds are pricey, starting at 50‚Ç¨. The atmosphere is lively, and the water is crystal clear, making it an ideal location for a day of relaxation. The bar offers a variety of refreshing cocktails and snacks, perfect for enjoying under the sun. While the sunbeds may be on the expensive side, the experience of lounging by the water makes it worth the splurge. Families and friends often gather here, adding to the cheerful vibe of the place. If you're looking for a fun day out, this spot is definitely worth considering.

Basically this is a small inlet on the coast with some interesting architecture, pleasant gardens and plenty of sun beds for hire.

Initial ‚Ç¨5 entry fee just gains access to the site. If you just want to wander around for an hour that's all you need.

Deck chairs, sun beds or kabanas are extra, ranging from ‚Ç¨20 to ‚Ç¨120. I felt this could have been clearer on the website. There's a couple of bars. The prices were a little premium but not too bad.

If you like movie history you can find the shooting locations for several movies on the site.

Despite reading the website and going there in person I'm still not sure where the spring actually springs from!

places.generalDescription: Nestled at the pinnacle of the historic Street of the Knights, the Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes stands as a magnificent testament to medieval architecture and history. Originally constructed by the Knights Hospitaller in the early 14th century, this imposing fortress was built atop an earlier Byzantine stronghold from the 7th century. Once serving as both a grand residence and administrative hub for these valiant knights, it has witnessed centuries of change.

sources.snippet: Essentially an occupying army, the Knights of St John transformed the northern segment of the Old Town during the 14th and 15th centuries, to create what‚Ä¶
sources.shortName: attractions Rhodes Town, Rhodes

sources.snippet: The Palace of the Grand Master is located at the end of Knights Street. This is one of the best-preserved castles of the Mediterranean and the symbol of the island. It was constructed by the Knights of Saint John in Medieval times and was reconstructed in the early 20th century.
sources.shortName: Top 40+ Sights & Landmarks in Rhodes

sources.snippet: **Dominating the old town‚Äôs skyline, the Palace of the Grand Master is a magnificent fortress that exudes grandeur. Its intricate details, impressive walls, and panoramic views from the top are a visual feast for both history enthusiasts and photography lovers.
sources.shortName: The most instagrammable spots in Rhodes

sources.snippet: Standing imperiously in the heart of the Old Town, this 14th-century palace is a must-see when you explore the capital. Built by the Knights of St. John, the palace was a Medieval residence for island governors and a holiday home for Mussolini.
sources.shortName: 51 Fun & Unusual Things to do in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: One of Greece‚Äôs most captivating medieval sites is the Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes, which now works as a museum. Admiring its collections of historical artefacts can embrace your art-loving eyes and soul.
sources.shortName: Destination ‚Äì Rodos Park

sources.snippet: The Palace of the Grand Master ‚Äì it was originally a Byzantine fortress which later housed the administrative center of the Order of Knights. Nowadays the ground floor holds two large exhibits about the city of Rhodes.
sources.shortName: Wandering around the Old Town of Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Walking through this imposing 14th-century structure with ancient art, architecture, exquisite marble, sculptures, and mosaics will give you a tiny glimpse of what life was like way back when.
sources.shortName: 11 Very Best Things To Do In Rhodes, Greece

places.name: Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes

reviews.text: Tickets are 20 EUR, but honestly, it's worth it, the palace is stunning, with beautifully preserved halls, mosaics and a real sense of history. The inner courtyard is impressive, and walking through the massive stone corridors feels like stepping back in time. Try to visit early in the day to avoid crowds and the heat. It's one of the must-see landmarks in Rhodes Old Town.

Plenty of fascinating history to explore, with what appears to be original decor or faithful reproductions. However, the ‚Ç¨20 entry fee felt a bit steep for what was on offer and didn't quite deliver value for money. The experience could be improved with more interactive elements to better engage visitors. Still, it's worth a visit if you're a history buff or interested in medieval architecture.

This place is so neat!  Tickets are 20Euro or about $23 USD.  Get there as early as you can, it gets crowded fast.  Amazing restored rooms and furniture and so much to learn and see.  It is an impressive building and beautifully decorated.  There is a wonderful museum at the end to view as well.

places.generalDescription: Lindos Beach is a popular destination located in a cove with a long stretch of sandy shoreline, perfect for swimming, sunbathing, and boating. It competes for attention with the ancient Acropolis of Lindos standing above it and the charming whitewashed houses cascading down the hillside. The beach offers fluffy yellow sand and clear waters ideal for families due to its shallow depth. Visitors can enjoy amenities such as bathrooms, showers, changing facilities, and sun loungers.

sources.snippet: On descending from the clifftop ruins of L√≠ndos Acropolis, you can relax on one of the best beaches on Rhodes. In a small bay enclosed by rocky headlands, the golden sands of Lindos Beach are lapped by clear, warm waters. There are plenty of sun loungers for hire and water sports are available if soaking up the sun is too laid-back for your taste.
sources.shortName: Best 15 Things To Do In Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: There are very cheap options and if you travel as a couple you won‚Äôt need a big vehicle to cruise around Rhodes. So we went with the cheapest rental car agency and payed around 85‚Ç¨ for 5 days. The white city of Lindos is the number one of the most instagrammable places in Rhodes.
sources.shortName: Most Instagrammable Places in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Going back to beaches, Lindos Beach is not only a good tanning spot but also very Instagram-worthy. Golden sand, boho sunbeds & umbrellas, and of course, the turquoise water in the cove. All these things make this beach one of the most popular in Rhodes.
sources.shortName: Rhodes, Greece: Full Guide to the Best Instagram Spots

places.name: Lindos Beach

reviews.text:
This sandy gem tucked in a small bay offers stunning views-especially with the ancient Acropolis towering above. The scenery is pure magic!

For just ‚Ç¨20, you get two sunbeds and a parasol (a fair price for the location). Clean showers are conveniently placed around the bay, and there's no shortage of great restaurants and shops nearby for snacks or full meals.

Ideal for sunbathing, swimming, or just soaking up the dreamy Greek vibes. A must-visit in Rhodes! ‚≠êÔ∏è

Overcrowded, no free zone, expensive umbrellas, tons of boats everywhere. Actually clean water if you never go out of it. Would not return. Probably better to visit by boat so you don't go near the beach. Sad thing is I'd rate it 5* if I came off season, probably.

We enjoyed very much this beach due to its calm water, nice sand, almost no waves and because it was close to facilities. The parking if you are lucky, is just on the edge of the beach. Be careful, you must park in the blue zone, and to pay 7‚Ç¨/day. But be there early because the parking is limited

places.generalDescription: The Archaeological Museum of Rhodes, located in the Old Town, is housed in the Medieval building of the hospital of the knights. It showcases ancient artifacts and art from excavations all over the island and small islets of Dodecanese. The collection includes figurines, vases, tomb groups, small objects from Ancient Ialyssos and Kameiros dating from Geometric to Roman times.

sources.shortName: attractions Rhodes Town, Rhodes

sources.snippet: There are countless picturesque spots in Rhodes Old Town (and you can check them out in our Rhodes Old Town self guided walking tour), but the Archaeological Museum of Rhodes is my absolute favorite with its awe-inspiring arches. The imposing structure was anciently the hospital of the knights of Saint John. Nowadays, it features a large collection of objects.
sources.shortName: The Best Rhodes Instagram Spots (+ a Map to Find Them)

sources.snippet: Other historical landmarks include the Archaeological Museum, the Cathedral of Panagia Castrou,the Clock Tower, the Suleiman‚Äôs Mosque, and the beautifully restored Street of Knights. ‚ÄòGetting lost‚Äô in the 200 alleys of the vivid city is recommended as you discover many little gems, like shops and restaurants.
sources.shortName: Destination ‚Äì Rodos Park

sources.snippet: The Archaeological Museum of Rhodes is housed in the Hospital of the Knights, one of the most important Medieval buildings. It consists of a large interior courtyard surrounded by a two-story colonnade. A rich collection from the Hellenistic period to the Early Christian times is exhibited in it.
sources.shortName: Top 40+ Sights & Landmarks in Rhodes

sources.snippet: Release your inner Indiana Jones and go exploring in this fascinating archaeological museum. Housed in a medieval building inside the Palace of the Grand Master, this is one of the top places to visit in Rhodes Old Town.
sources.shortName: 51 Fun & Unusual Things to do in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: The Archeological Museum of Rhodes ‚Äì the best museum in the Dodecanese that holds finds from the island, including relics, urns and marble statues dating back to ancient times.
sources.shortName: Wandering around the Old Town of Rhodes, Greece

places.name: Archaeological Museum of Rhodes

reviews.text: Absolutely amazing! The first floor rooms are stuffed with beautiful ancient artefacts, then through the church area into rooms full of statues. Don't miss going outside into the garden area - enormous mosaics are displayed in a special area with ponds and citrus trees. I spent hours in here - after 3pm I pretty much had it all to myself.

An absolute must visit I'm so serious. you enter somewhere rather empty and once you step into the real museum section it's like it comes to life, there's SO much theres literally corners just filled with pillars and such because I can only assume they have so many that they don't know what to do with them?? üò≠ History from all throughout the ages in a building that reflects that, it's honestly all just beautiful I was awestruck. I could've been there all day I think. ‚Ç¨10 for adults and free for under 18s (maybe 21??) and moree than worth the price. Genuinely really miss it, wish I was there now.

Quick warning however!! There are some rather uneven stairs with no handrails so if this is something you might struggle with I wouldn't say not to visit but I'd definitely say to be prepared for it. Not to call him out but my grandad stumbled on them and definitely could've hurt himself rather badly, we were lucky he was alright. Could happen to anyone, take care with those stairs

An enormous collection housed in a beautiful structure, the Museum is a must see! A carefully curated history of Rhodes in antiquity, there are hundreds of artefacts to admire. Allow plenty of time but be aware some galleries do not permit photography! Other exhibitions are not open on a Tuesday.

There are some idyllic little gardens to admire too along the way, and the structure itself is beautiful. Highly recommended, just allow plenty of time!

places.generalDescription: The Holy Monastery of the Virgin Mary Tsambika (Kyra Psili) is a small Byzantine-era monastery located on a hill overlooking the sea. It houses the church with the miraculous icon of the Virgin Mary, known as Panagia Tsambika, making it a significant religious site for childless women who often leave baby dolls as offerings. The monastery also offers stunning panoramic views over the northern part of Rhodes and requires climbing around 300 steps to reach it.

sources.snippet: Another one for the hiking boots, the Monastery of Tsambika sits atop 350 steep steps but its long-range viewing points are second to none. On reaching the top of the hill you will be met by a tiny white Byzantine church and views of the coastline. Legend has it that women facing fertility difficulties climbed to the church to pray to the Virgin for help with conceiving, something that it still done today.
sources.shortName: 7 stunning selfie spots in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Tsamb√≠ka Monastery sits on the peak of a rocky promontory overlooking the east coast of the island. It is believed that the Virgin, to whom the monastery is dedicated, can make women fertile. Consequently, the tiny, vaulted 17th-century monastic church, which retains fresco fragments, is a magnet for childless women.
sources.shortName: Best 15 Things To Do In Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: **Situated atop a hill, the Tsambika Monastery not only offers a glimpse into local religious culture but also panoramic views of the island‚Äôs coastline. The climb is rewarding, and the serene surroundings make for captivating photographs.
sources.shortName: The most instagrammable spots in Rhodes

sources.snippet: Tsambika Monastery: Perched atop a hill overlooking Tsambika Beach, Tsambika Monastery provides panoramic views of the coastline. As the sun sets over the sea, the colors of the sky create a stunning backdrop for this sacred site.
sources.siteName: Kariba Travel Group Excursions and Private Tours in Rhodes Island
sources.shortName: Stunning sunset views from various vantage points.-Kariba Travel

sources.snippet: Tsambika Monastery is another place you should visit in Rhodes. The Monastery is, in fact, a really small Byzantine church built on top of the mountain. You have to climb more than 300 steps to get there!
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Rhodes | Attractions + Tips

sources.snippet: Yeah, you might be a little sozzled if you do this in the midday heat, but I promise you it‚Äôs worth it!. Just make sure to pack lots of water and sunblock.
sources.shortName: 11 Very Best Things To Do In Rhodes, Greece

places.name: Holy Monastery of the Virgin Mary Tsambika (Kyra Psili)

reviews.text:
The Holy Monastery of the Virgin Mary offers an absolutely stunning view over Tsambika Beach - truly breathtaking and totally worth the effort.

Getting to the top, though, is no joke! There are around 300 steps, and with the heat, it became quite a challenge. We had to stop for breaks several times, so make sure to bring water, wear proper shoes, and avoid the hottest part of the day if you can.

The monastery itself is small but peaceful and charming, with a serene atmosphere. There's a respectful dress code so remember to cover-up just in case.

Even though the hike is tough, the view from the top makes it 100% worth it - perfect for taking photos and enjoying a quiet moment above the beach.

highly recommend visiting this peaceful and sacred place. It is very beautiful, calm, and magical. Here you can write your family's names and wishes in the book, offer a prayer, and feel a deep sense of peace in your heart. It is a truly spiritual experience. Recommend go there on sunset time, around 7pm.

View worth to climbe about 300 steps in 30 degrees. It's not so hot because path goes through forest so many shades and mountain breeze refreshing. Take water is highly recommend.

It takes around one hour to climb up and go down (from parking where steps starts).

places.generalDescription: Farma of Rhodes is a captivating petting zoo boasting over 100 friendly animals, including deers, camels, donkeys, lemurs, and ostriches. Visitors can interact with the animals through feeding and petting experiences while capturing memorable selfies. Notably, Farma of Rhodes is the exclusive location in Rhodes where playful Lemurs can be found and interacted with.

sources.snippet: Get hands-on at the Farma of Rhodes, where a menagerie of unusual inhabitants is waiting to greet you. Have a go at feeding the ostriches and kangaroos or try taking a selfie with a llama. Fancy hanging out with the camels?.
sources.shortName: 51 Fun & Unusual Things to do in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Farma of Rhodes provides a unique interactive experience where you can pet, feed and take pictures with many exotic animals, including ostriches, lemurs, ponies, llamas and kangaroos.
sources.shortName: Top 40+ Sights & Landmarks in Rhodes

places.name: Farma of Rhodes | Petting Zoo

reviews.text:
I would recommend Farma Of Rhodes to anyone visiting. It's is such a special and beautiful place to visit as a couple or a family. You can see the care the staff give to the animals and how much this place means to them.

We visited a year ago and had to come back as it was a highlight of our holiday. The guides at each point are helpful and so knowledgeable however the lady who is the keeper in the lemur enclosure is just amazing. Her passion and love for the lemurs shine through and her knowledge is exceptional. She is an absolute credit to the farm.

The lemur experience is one I would tell everyone to do and is not one to be missed. My kids love it each time we have visited and always reflect back as one of their best times in rhodes.

There is also a lovely cafe with amazing milkshakes that the kids raved about. An amazing day out and one I would recommend over and over again. We will be back

Had a really pleasant experience. The zoo had a lot of animals for it's size. You could pet and feed most of them and they were all very friendly.
They had a lovely experience with the lemurs, where you could go in their area, feed them, pet them and play around with them. If you have kids they will love it.
I would definitely suggest, as it offers things you will not get in other farms or zoos.
There is plenty of parking available.

I just visited Farma Zoo in Rhodes and it was honestly the best zoo experience I've ever had! I've been to many zoos in different countries, but this one truly stands out. The variety of animals is small ‚Äì you'll find donkeys, sheep, raccoons, ducks, lemurs and a few others ‚Äì but what makes it special is the atmosphere.

You can clearly see that the animals are happy, well cared for, and treated with love. The staff are absolutely wonderful ‚Äì so friendly and passionate about what they do. They even give the animals names, which makes the whole experience feel much more personal and heartwarming.

One of the highlights for me was being able to feed the lemurs ‚Äì such a fun and unique experience! It doesn't feel like a typical zoo, but more like a place where animals and people connect in the right way. I left with such a positive feeling and so many great memories.

places.generalDescription: Butterflies Valley, located on the Greek island of Rhodes, is a 600-acre nature park that serves as a summer home for numerous butterflies. The valley is particularly popular from late May to late September when thousands of Jersey tiger moths gather in the shaded canyon, which boasts the only natural forest of Oriental Sweetgum trees in Europe. Visitors can explore walking trails and benches while being surrounded by formidable walls and medieval buildings in the nearby Old Town of Rhodes.

sources.snippet: The valley of Butterflies (Petaloudes) is one of the most atractive destinations on the island. During late summer, especially August, thousands of butterflies gather in the valley to reproduce. The valley offers a nice walk through lush greenery and noumerous spots for photo-shooting, while at the end of tne route you will find the Kalopetra monastery, where can enjoy the view  and a refreshment.
sources.siteName: RhodesGuide.com - Rhodes Rhodos Rodos Greece Travel Guide
sources.shortName: Top Photography Locations on Rhodes, part 1

sources.snippet: In this verdant valley, lush sweetgum trees, running streams, small waterfalls, rocky trails, and millions of butterflies create a paradise on earth. This is a reproduction spot for butterflies over the summer months, so visitors are asked to be careful.
sources.shortName: Top 40+ Sights & Landmarks in Rhodes

sources.snippet: Surround yourself with thousands of dancing butterflies in this lush natural reserve in western Rhodes. Come between Spring and Fall to witness dazzling clouds of color performing astonishing aerial acrobatics right before your eyes.
sources.shortName: 51 Fun & Unusual Things to do in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: **A nature lover‚Äôs paradise, Butterfly Valley is home to thousands of colorful butterflies during the summer months. Walking through the lush forested area and capturing the delicate creatures on camera is a magical experience.
sources.shortName: The most instagrammable spots in Rhodes

places.name: Butterflies Valley

reviews.text:
üåüüåüüåüüåüüåü
Magical Butterfly Valley ‚Äì A Hidden Natural Wonder in Rhodes

Visiting Butterfly Valley (Petaloudes) in Rhodes is like stepping into a living fairytale. Nestled in a lush, shaded gorge, this enchanting place is home to millions of butterflies during the summer months - a truly mesmerizing sight as they flutter among the trees, especially the beautiful Jersey tiger moths with their striking orange underwings.

The valley itself is a cool, peaceful escape from the heat, filled with winding paths, wooden bridges, waterfalls, and streams. The atmosphere is serene, with the sound of running water and rustling leaves accompanying you along the way. It's a nature lover's paradise and one of the most unique experiences on the island.

BUT - be prepared! The walk is no joke. You'll be heading uphill and downhill quite a bit, so make sure to wear good sneakers and bring plenty of water, especially on hot days. There are lots of stairs and uneven terrain, but the effort is absolutely worth it for the views, the butterflies, and the overall experience.

Whether you're into nature, photography, or just looking to enjoy something different and peaceful, Butterfly Valley is a must-visit. It's not just a tourist attraction - it's a natural wonder that leaves you in awe.

Tip: Go early in the day to avoid the crowds and catch the butterflies while they're most active.

When it comes to nature on Rhodes, this is indeed an interesting valley. The trail consists of two stages: you walk through a gorge among trees and shrubs, along a stream, with the occasional small waterfall or pond. Wooden footbridges, benches to rest on, and the occasional butterfly create a pleasant atmosphere.
However, the path goes uphill, with plenty of stone steps, so in 40¬∞C heat (we had 49¬∞C that day ‚Äì we wanted to cool down) this activity is not for everyone. At the beginning, in the middle, and at the end of the trail, there are toilet facilities (they cost ‚Ç¨0.50 ‚Äì a bit of a pity that it's not free when you eat in the restaurant or in the park), restaurants, and rest areas. We had a coffee, and it was okay.
In August 2025, the entrance fee is ‚Ç¨6. You walk uphill in a crowd, on a stone path, and ‚Äúadmire‚Äù the charms of the valley. In my opinion, those charms are rather average. The price is adequate for the attraction. Worth a visit, but it's not on the TOP list for Rhodes.

The Valley of the Butterflies is a hidden gem in Rhodes ‚Äì peaceful, unique, and absolutely worth a visit. Walking through the shaded paths surrounded by lush greenery and waterfalls feels like stepping into another world. During the summer months, thousands of butterflies gather here, creating a magical atmosphere that's hard to describe in words.

Take your time to enjoy the calm, listen to the sound of water and nature, and if you can, climb up to the monastery at the top for a beautiful panoramic view. Wear comfortable shoes ‚Äì it's a gentle hike but with some steps ‚Äì and bring your camera, because every corner is a picture waiting to happen.

A place where nature shows its most delicate side. Truly unforgettable!

places.generalDescription: Perched on a hill overlooking the Aegean Sea, Kritinia Castle, also known as Kastello to locals, is a historic Venetian/Byzantine castle dating back to 1472. Although now in ruins, the castle still showcases its former grandeur. Visitors can reach the site by taking a bus to Kritinia and walking or driving up the dirt track.

sources.snippet: I did this day trip which took us to Kritinia Castle, a Venetian castle ruin with incredible views across the sea. We also did a wine and honey tasting just outside the town of Embonas. Rhodes is known for its dry white wine and sweet wines.
sources.shortName: The Best Things To do in Rhodes, Greece: A Rhodes Itinerary

sources.snippet: Kritinia Castle: Situated on the west coast of Rhodes, Kritinia Castle offers spectacular sunset views over the surrounding countryside and the sea. Climb to the top of the castle ruins for an unparalleled vantage point.
sources.siteName: Kariba Travel Group Excursions and Private Tours in Rhodes Island
sources.shortName: Stunning sunset views from various vantage points.-Kariba Travel

sources.snippet: Pretend to be knights of the realm as you stride around the ruins of Kritinia Castle in western Rhodes. Strategically positioned on a hill overlooking the Aegean, the castle enjoys some of the best views on the island.
sources.shortName: 51 Fun & Unusual Things to do in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Ever wondered how the Venetians watched the sunset in Rhodes during their stay on the island?. If yes, be sure to check out Kritinia Castle. The Knights of St. John built Kritinia Castle in 1472.
sources.shortName: 6 Best Places to Watch Sunset in Rhodes island

places.name: Kritinia Castle

reviews.text: Rather remote, but beautiful little ruin of a castle that must have been very impressive in the past. From the top of the ruin you have an impressive view into the bay and the small islands in the vicinity. On a clear day you can see the coastline of Turkey in the distance. In the public section there is no roof structure left, so in the very unlikely event of rainfall you would not have any meaningful cover. Great that this precious spot is free of charge.
Ruins of a castle with a nice view. Great spot for sunset. The entrance was free. It's a pity that it is not maintained

While driving around the island, we noticed signs pointing to the castle ruins and decided to make a spontaneous detour. The road leading up to the site is mostly tarmac and fairly accessible, with just a few short but steep sections near the top. Our small rental car managed it with no issues.

There's a free car park right by the castle that can hold around 15 cars, which was a nice bonus. Entry to the ruins is also free, accessed via a set of built steps. Just a note ‚Äì not suitable for a wheelchair access, unfortunately.

Once you reach the top, the views are absolutely breathtaking and make the short trek well worth it. We also noticed a small caf√© nearby, but we didn't stop in so can't comment on the food or service.

Overall, it's a great little stop if you're exploring the island ‚Äì highly recommended if you've got an hour to spare and fancy a bita bit of history paired with stunning scenery.

places.generalDescription: Rhodes is a treasure trove of historical sites, and the Street of the Knights of Rhodes is a must-visit. This cobbled medieval street is lined with seven inns, each representing the countries of origin for the Knights of St. John. The architecture along this street is considered one of the finest examples of Gothic urbanism, making it a picturesque and historically significant area to explore.

sources.snippet: The Jewish Quarter, an enclave of narrow lanes in the Old Town‚Äôs southeast corner, centres on Plateia Evreon Martyron (Square of the Jewish Martyrs).
sources.shortName: attractions Rhodes Town, Rhodes

sources.snippet: 00 NEW SEE&DO - RENAME ITPalace of Grand MasterStreet of the KnightsAcropolis of RhodesArchaeological MuseumAquariumGreat HammamMunicipal Art GalleryPanagia tou KastrouHoly TrinityChurch of AnnunciationPath of GodsModern Art MuseumJewish MuseumRodini ParkThrone of HeliosOur Lady of VictoryCave of the Archangel Michael PanormitisCatholic ChurchesChurch of Agia Triada
sources.shortName: Rhodes Town: Photos, Map, See & Do

sources.snippet: Other historical landmarks include the Archaeological Museum, the Cathedral of Panagia Castrou,the Clock Tower, the Suleiman‚Äôs Mosque, and the beautifully restored Street of Knights. ‚ÄòGetting lost‚Äô in the 200 alleys of the vivid city is recommended as you discover many little gems, like shops and restaurants.
sources.shortName: Destination ‚Äì Rodos Park

sources.snippet: Similarly to the Three Windmills, this is a well-known spot in Old Town Rhodes. The Street of Knights is the pinnacle of traveling back to Medieval times because of ancient cobblestones lining the long alleyway. By standing in the middle of the street, you can get this dreamy shot below.
sources.shortName: Rhodes, Greece: Full Guide to the Best Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: Tip: If you need some respite from the heat of the Mediterranean sun on a hot summer‚Äôs day, then retreat to the cool cobbled alleyways of the medieval Old Town and find a cafe to perch yourself for a while.
sources.shortName: 11 Absolute Best Things To Do In Rhodes Town, Greece

places.name: Street of the Knights of Rhodes

reviews.text: What a wonderful place.  A labyrinth of small lanes with a mix of homes,  shops, cafes and restaurants.  You can easily get lost as its just turn after turn.... all set within the walls of an old part of Rhodes main city.  If you've been to Lindos, it's very similar except in lindos everything is white and here all the old buildings are bare stone. lots of craftsman making things as well.  Didn't seem to be a rip off, just a great experience and definitely recommended.

Walking down the Street of the Knights (ŒüŒ¥œåœÇ ŒôœÄœÄŒøœÑœéŒΩ) in Rhodes is like stepping into a living manuscript of medieval Europe. Perfectly preserved and hauntingly beautiful, this cobbled thoroughfare-once the ceremonial heart of the Knights Hospitaller-remains one of the most evocative streets in all of Europe.

Lined with austere yet majestic stone fa√ßades, each auberge tells a silent tale of the Order's different Langues, or tongues-representing the various nations of the knights. The architecture is sober, noble, and powerful, just like the ideals the knights professed to defend. As you ascend slowly toward the Palace of the Grand Master, each step seems to echo with history.

There are no neon signs here, no tourist traps cluttering the view-just the hush of centuries under your feet and above your head. The street rewards those who walk it slowly, who look up, and who listen carefully.

To visit Rhodes without walking this street would be to visit Venice and miss the canals, or Cairo and skip the pyramids. It's not just a place-it's an experience of time carved in stone.

Excellent. A bucket list visit for me, with a really good explanatory series of plaques in an alley to your left about halfway up. Provides a lot of helpful context. Interestingly, a poster in the palace's museum even suggests that the 'langues' were a precursor to the EU. A bit of a stretch to my mind; but there's no doubting the multicultural nature of the separate inns, when viewed as a whole community.
Visit early for the best views!

places.generalDescription: Filerimos Monastery, located on Filerimos Hill in the Greek island of Rhodes, is a historical site with religious significance dating back to the 8th century BC. The monastery was built in the 10th century AD by the Order of the Knights of St. John and has been restored in the early 20th century. Surrounded by lush greenery, this stone structure is a popular tourist attraction and offers visitors a glimpse into its medieval architecture with domed arches.

sources.snippet: Of all the historical sites in Rhodes, this is one of the most unusual. Standing proud on a wide plateau above Ialyssos town, the 15th-century Filerimos Monastery was designed in a Gothic style. It is quite unlike other buildings on the island.
sources.shortName: 51 Fun & Unusual Things to do in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Filerimos Monastery is one of the most overlooked attractions in Rhodes. Despite being an important cultural landmark, the Byzantine monastery is also the ideal location for taking some amazing photos. First, because of the views.
sources.shortName: The Best Rhodes Instagram Spots (+ a Map to Find Them)

sources.snippet: This monastery was constructed on the hill of Filerimos, close to the site of Ancient Ialyssos. It was built by the Knights of Saint John in Medieval times but was reconstructed in the early 20th century.
sources.shortName: Top 40+ Sights & Landmarks in Rhodes

places.name: Filerimos Monastery

reviews.text: An absolutely amazing place full of ancient history! Missed this last year but so glad we went this year! The views are spectacular! Lots of peacocks live there too and they like showing off! Choose your time wisely though as can get very busy!

Cost 10 Euros to enter the site. Great views towards the north and West. Number of Peacocks and their displays impressive. Lovely green wooded environment surrounding the site. Two hours sufficient to visit site and surrounding areas.

At this place, I was surprised by both the peacocks and the rich history that has been preserved here. From the monastery to the castle. You can walk around it crisscross. Beautiful views await you here, beautiful buildings that you can also see from the inside. Entrance to the castle and monastery grounds is paid. The grounds are well-maintained and clean, and the toilets were clean too.

places.generalDescription: Viewpoint Anthony Quinn Bay offers breathtaking views of the surrounding bays, including Ladiko Beach and Faliraki Beach. The road to access it is steep and narrow, making it a bit challenging for drivers, but the stunning vistas make it worth the effort. It's recommended to visit early in the morning or before sunset due to high temperatures during the day.

sources.snippet: Named after famous actor Anthony Quinn, (he purchased the inlet following the filming of ‚ÄòThe Guns of Navarone‚Äô), this hidden gem is a must see destination in Rhodes. Crystal clear waters tinted emerald green due to the vegetation surrounding the bay, make for an unrivalled selfie backdrop and a visit you won‚Äôt necessarily need a picture to remember. The miniature beach on the east coast of the island gives you a chance to appreciate the natural beauty of your surroundings both above and below water.
sources.shortName: 7 stunning selfie spots in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: The next stop on the list for bringing you Instagram pictures to another level is the Anthony Quinn Bay ‚Äì and yes it is named after the famous actor who came here for filming in 1961. It is a very scenic bay with crystal clear water and a shallow sloping beach ‚Äì perfect for a relaxing day combined with some snorkeling. We came here in the afternoon and enjoyed a wonderful sunset while everyone else left for dinner.
sources.shortName: Most Instagrammable Places in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Aside from St. Paul‚Äôs Bay in Lindos, Anthony Quinn Bay is another must-visit location for photography lovers. The beautiful bay has calm and crystal-clear waters with picturesque stairs leading down to the pebble beach. Besides shooting pictures in the water by the protruding rocks, there is also a panoramic viewpoint(Anthony Quinn Viewpoint) located higher up adjacent to the bay.
sources.shortName: Rhodes, Greece: Full Guide to the Best Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: Anthony Quinn Bay: Named after the famous actor who fell in love with its beauty while filming ‚ÄúThe Guns of Navarone,‚Äù Anthony Quinn Bay is renowned for its crystal-clear waters and rocky surroundings. Watching the sunset from this idyllic spot is a truly romantic experience.
sources.siteName: Kariba Travel Group Excursions and Private Tours in Rhodes Island
sources.shortName: Stunning sunset views from various vantage points.-Kariba Travel

sources.snippet: Hollywood star Anthony Quinn engraved its name in Rhodes history by acquiring the bay in the 60s. Luckily for us, the iconic bay became a public property again in 1984. Anthony Quinn Bay with its rocky beach is definitely one of the most beautiful sights on the island.
sources.shortName: The Best Rhodes Instagram Spots (+ a Map to Find Them)

sources.snippet: Glide through the emerald waters of Anthony Quinn Bay and spend a leisurely day relaxing at the beach. This is the best place to go snorkeling in Rhodes, so strap on your gear and dive below the surface to discover a marine world filled with mystery and majesty.
sources.shortName: 51 Fun & Unusual Things to do in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Move on to the green-and-blue-watered Anthony Quinn Beach (so-called because the American actor fell in love with the bay during the filming of the Guns of Navarone). And, finally, visit the pure fine sand of Tsambika and Agathi.
sources.shortName: 8 Unique Things To Do Beyond The Beach

places.name: Anthony Quinn Bay viewpoint

reviews.text: Magnificent view and great area. It would have been possible to drive all the way up, but we chickened out and parked halfway. The hike up was demanding in the 37C heat, but it was all worth it.

Must visited spot. Driving is a little hard specially if you don't have a good car. You can stop in many parking spots on the way up and continue hiking not so difficult. Anyhow must seen and don't miss it

Perfect for family of x2 adults and x2 teens. We found a parking space after midday and made ourselves a space on the beach. If you are driving, search ratjer for Ladiko Bay which is the same  thing. Yes, it's busy but not over crowded. The water is magical. We snorkelled over to Anthony Quinn Bay which is better suited for adults only as it's rocky and not suitable for paddling. There is a ladder to get into the water. Many day cruise boats stop here for a quick snorkelling/swimming break.  There is a bar at Ladiko Bay but this time we had taken our own. Most people use water shoes. Considering how windy it was in Faliraki,  the Bay was quite sheltered.

places.generalDescription: Traganou Beach, located on the northeast shore of Rhodes Island, offers a serene and unspoiled atmosphere due to its pebbled surface that deters large crowds. This 20-minute drive south of Rhodes Town is a haven for sunseekers and beach enthusiasts, providing parasols, loungers, and calm waters ideal for swimming and snorkeling. The beach also features Traganou Cave on its north side for exploration.

sources.snippet: You know you have found the best beach when it is full of locals and it was exactly that!. Beautiful clear blue sea which is wavy in the morning and very calm in the afternoon. It is a rock beach ‚Äì so bring your watershoes, otherwise the pebbles are hot and painful specially at noon.
sources.shortName: Most Instagrammable Places in Rhodes, Greece

places.name: Traganou Beach

reviews.text: This beach is a very quiet family oriented beach. Parking is great, lots of space and it's free. The beach has many pebbles everywhere so, I highly recommend wearing water shoes if you are sensitive on your feet. The water so clean and clear. bring your snorkelling gear with you. The cave and rock formations are so picturesque that you will enjoy taking photos. You can sit in the cave if you want to stay out from the sun. The sun beds and umbrella is 15 euros very reasonable compared to other beaches we did our research others were asking 25 to 30 euros way too much! You are more than welcome to bring a packed lunch or enjoy the restaurant which has great food!

A pebble beach with crystal-clear water. The sunbed and umbrella fee is ‚Ç¨10 for one person and ‚Ç¨15 for two. For those who prefer not to pay, there are some shaded areas available for free use. There are also nice places nearby for food and drinks.

My experience at Traganou Beach was nothing short of amazing! The beach has  pebbles, but they're small they don't bother you at all-just bring water shoes if you're extra sensitive. The water is crystal clear, perfect for swimming and snorkeling around the nearby caves and rock formations (don't miss exploring them!).

The vibe here is pure chillaxation-no crowds, just serene beauty. A pair of sunbeds and a parasol cost only ‚Ç¨15. Getting here is easy too: take the bus, and it's just a 10-minute walk from the stop.

The Traganou Taverna nearby serves delicious, affordable food-the perfect post-beach feast or to grab an ice cold beer or a coffee. They have a great barisrta.

Hands down, this was the best beach day of my life! Highly recommend for anyone visiting Rhodes. üíô

places.generalDescription: Filerimos is a small hill covered in cedar trees, featuring a medieval monastery and offering panoramic views over the bay. The route to Filerimos starts at the foot of the hill, accessible via the western road and passing through Ialysos. Along the way, visitors can explore ancient ruins dating back to 3rd millennium BC and enjoy scenic landscapes.

sources.snippet: Filerimos Hill is another wonderful site to go to not only during daytime but especially so at twilight to watch the sunset in Rhodes. You will surely feel the spiritual aura of the area while walking down the Cavalry Route to the big cross. This is the best place to be not just to enjoy the stunning sunset show with your eyes as it is also great for replenishing your soul.
sources.shortName: 6 Best Places to Watch Sunset in Rhodes island

sources.snippet: Filerimos is a truly captivating destination that can be enjoyed both during the day and in the evening. As you embark on the Calvary route leading towards the imposing cross, you will be enveloped by a palpable sense of spirituality. The experience promises not only a feast for your eyes with a stunning sunset, but also a nourishment for your soul.
sources.shortName: The 5 Best Sunset spots in Rhodes | Rhodes guide

places.name: Filerimos

reviews.text: The huge centenary cross is awesome, with fantastic views from its base. It is a shame that you can no longer climb inside it now, but it is still worth the visit. The beautifully maintained area around is home to goats and peacocks. The access via the pilgrims walk is spoiled since the removal of the bronze plaques.
Monastery was nice albeit a bit expensive for its size. Views were amazing and lots of peacocks to see and feed. Surrounding area was great to hike around too

Want to get away from the hassle of streets, pool, and beaches for a couple of hours?
Once you make it to the top of the hill, you can have an incredibly relaxing walk around the monastery, it's grounds and along to the viewpoint.
There's a cafe for refreshments and peacocks, too.
If not part of an organised group, there was a 10 Euro entrance charge for casual tourists, but it was worth it.

places.generalDescription: The Acropolis of Rhodes is a significant ancient site located in the capital of the island, on Monte Smith. It features various structures such as a stadium and theater, offering visitors a glimpse into the long-standing settlement's history. Additionally, nearby attractions include the Acropolis of Lindos and ancient Minoan artifacts dating back over 3,000 years. Nature enthusiasts can explore the Valley of Butterflies with its unique flora and fauna.

sources.snippet: The main gallery of the four-part Modern Greek Art Museum, near the New Town‚Äôs northern tip, holds paintings, engravings and sculptures by some of Greece‚Ä¶
sources.shortName: attractions Rhodes Town, Rhodes

sources.snippet: 00 NEW SEE&DO - RENAME ITPalace of Grand MasterStreet of the KnightsAcropolis of RhodesArchaeological MuseumAquariumGreat HammamMunicipal Art GalleryPanagia tou KastrouHoly TrinityChurch of AnnunciationPath of GodsModern Art MuseumJewish MuseumRodini ParkThrone of HeliosOur Lady of VictoryCave of the Archangel Michael PanormitisCatholic ChurchesChurch of Agia Triada
sources.shortName: Rhodes Town: Photos, Map, See & Do

sources.snippet: The Acropolis of Rhodes perched on top of Monte Smith Hill is one of the perfect examples of architecture from  ancient Greece. Experiencing twilight in this historic acropolis is something you will surely treasure for a lifetime. It is the most well-preserved and complete ancient complex on Rhodes island.
sources.shortName: 6 Best Places to Watch Sunset in Rhodes island

sources.snippet: Once a bustling arena of temples, public buildings, and even a stadium, the Acropolis today stands as a proud testament to ancient Greek civilizations. Sitting on a hillside overlooking Rhodes Town, the eye-catching ruins of this historic settlement are a fascinating window into past grandeur.
sources.shortName: 51 Fun & Unusual Things to do in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: The Acropolis of Rhodes offers 2 things: Great archaeological interest and truly spectacular sunsets. Whether you are interested in one of these two or both, don't miss this unique location. Authored by Spyros Spyropoulos
sources.siteName: RhodesGuide.com - Rhodes Rhodos Rodos Greece Travel Guide
sources.shortName: Top Photography Locations on Rhodes, part 1
Destination ‚Äì Rodos Park

places.name: Acropolis of Rhodes

reviews.text: We were told by hotel staff that it wasn't worth the walk and I couldn't disagree MORE. The actual temple was under restoration and was covered in scaffolding but honestly the rest made up for it all. Beautiful stadium, theatre and all around layout. Most sites don't mention that there's also a temple to Artemis besides the one to Apollo which was the one with scaffolding so that was a really pleasant surprise. Amazing views from the top too. MAKE SURE YOU KNOW HOW TO GET THERE üò≠üò≠ the signs are super misleading. There was loads of signs inside through with some sick information so I was loving that.

Step Back in Time ‚Äì Exploring the Acropolis of Rhodes and Surrounding Ancient Wonders

Visiting the Acropolis of Rhodes is like walking through a portal into ancient history. Perched on Monte Smith hill and surrounded by greenery, the site is a treasure trove of remarkable ruins, each whispering stories from over 2,300 years ago.

Start your journey with the Olympic Stadium, beautifully preserved and still echoing the spirit of ancient athleticism. You can almost picture the competitions that once took place here. Just a short walk away, you'll find the small but impressive Odeon, a Roman-era theater that once hosted music and poetry performances ‚Äì it's a peaceful spot that brings the grandeur of the past to life.

The crown jewel, of course, is the Temple of Apollo, with its tall columns standing proudly against the sky. Though partially restored, the site still evokes the sacred atmosphere of classical worship. As you explore further, you'll come across scattered ruins, columns, and steps that once formed temples, sanctuaries, and public spaces - all part of the ancient city's rich tapestry.

Besides the historical significance, the views from the hilltop are absolutely stunning. Overlooking the sea and the modern town of Rhodes, it's a perfect mix of natural beauty and cultural depth. Don't be surprised if you lose track of time - there's something new to admire around every corner.

A few tips:
‚Ä¢	Wear comfortable sneakers ‚Äì the paths are uneven, and you'll be doing a fair bit of walking.
‚Ä¢	Bring plenty of water, especially in summer ‚Äì shade is limited, and the sun can be intense.
‚Ä¢	A camera is a must ‚Äì both for the ruins and the sweeping panoramic views.

In short: This area is a must-see for history lovers, architecture buffs, or anyone who wants to experience the soul of ancient Greece. It's not just a sightseeing spot - it's an experience that transports you centuries into the past. Don't miss it while you're in Rhodes!

The Acropolis of Rhodes (Monte Smith) is an impressive historical site with many layers of history. üèõÔ∏è You can explore the Temple of Apollo, the ancient stadium, and the restored theater, all set in a beautiful landscape with wide views over Rhodes and the sea. üåÖ

However, some parts of what you see today were reconstructed during the Italian occupation in the 1930s. The Italians tried to ‚Äúrecreate‚Äù ancient Rhodes, but often used wrong methods and modern materials like concrete, which doesn't reflect the original look or technique. üèóÔ∏è While it helped preserve parts of the site, it also makes some reconstructions appear inauthentic.
